[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary (e.g., "enlightened and emancipated men of science," "quasi-biological") may hinder readability for modern readers.
[SYNTAX]: Extremely long, complex sentences (e.g., "Was it not accepted by all of us...") risk overwhelming clarity.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shift from personal anecdote (Tyndall’s influence) to unrelated historical event (Lincoln-Davis peace talks) without clear thematic connection.
[TRANSITION]: Ideas (e.g., Spencer’s philosophy, Darwin/James citations) are logically sequenced internally but lack smooth bridges between paragraphs.

[COMPLEXITY]: Excessively long, dense sentences with multiple embedded clauses (e.g., "It will perhaps be said...").
[LEXICON]: Overuse of abstract, specialized terminology (e.g., "Unknowable," "universal causation") without contextualization.
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt, unmarked shift to narrative fragment ("The Minister could not help smiling...") disrupting flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Illogical inclusion of unrelated narrative snippet ("The Minister...") with no thematic or contextual connection.
[CLARITY]: Assumed familiarity with Spencer’s works and philosophical debates (e.g., "sixteen articles of the Spencerian creed") without explanation.
[LOGIC]: Circular reasoning in defending Spencer’s "all-inclusive" interpretation while acknowledging its limitations.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures may impede smooth reading.
[LEXICON]: Formal vocabulary and dense philosophical terminology.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unconnected paragraph about artistic works disrupts thematic flow.
[TRANSITION]: Sudden shifts between philosophical critiques (e.g., Russell, Bergson) and Spencer’s ideas.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unconnected shifts between philosophical, narrative, historical, and scientific topics (e.g., Adolphe/Marie story, Rio Grande influence).
[TRANSITION]: No logical bridges or explanations linking disparate sections.

[COMPLEXITY]: Excessively dense and lengthy sentences may impede smooth reading.

[TRANSITION]: Occasional abrupt shifts between critiques of Spencer and illustrative examples.

[SYNTAX]: Extended, densely packed sentences require careful parsing.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unrelated biographical paragraph disrupts thematic continuity.
[TRANSITION]: Lack of logical connection between emergent properties discussion and historical anecdote.

[SYNTAX]: Extremely long, nested sentences (e.g., "It must be confessed...") disrupt flow.
